mongo – MongoDB interface¶

mongo.base¶

class orca.mongo.base.FetcherBase(debug_on=True, datetime_index=False, reindex=False, date_check=False, delay=1)[source]¶

Bases: object

Base class for mongo fetchers.

Parameters:
  • debug_on (boolean) – Enable/Disable debug level messages. Default: True
  • datetime_index (boolean) – Whether to use DatetimeIndex or list of date strings. Default: False
  • reindex (boolean) – Whether to use full sids as columns in DataFrame. Default: False
  • date_check (boolean) – Whethter to check if passed date-related parameters are valid. Default: False
  • delay (int) – Delay fetched data in fetch_history(). Default: 1

Note

This is a base class and should not be used directly.

__metaclass__¶

alias of ABCMeta

set_debug_mode(debug_on)[source]¶

Enable/Disable debug level message in data fetchers. This is enabled by default.

debug(msg)[source]¶

Logs a message with level DEBUG on the alpha logger.

info(msg)[source]¶

Logs a message with level INFO on the alpha logger.

warning(msg)[source]¶

Logs a message with level WARNING on the alpha logger.

error(msg)[source]¶

Logs a message with level ERROR on the alpha logger.

critical(msg)[source]¶

Logs a message with level CRITICAL on the alpha logger.

fetch(dname, startdate, enddate=None, backdays=0, **kwargs)[source]¶

Override(mandatory) to fetch data within two endpoints.

Parameters:
  • dname (str) – Name of the data
  • startdate (str, int) – The left (may not be the actual) endpoint
  • enddate (str, int, None) – The right endpoint. Default: None, defaults to the last date
  • backdays (int) – This will shift (left/right: >/< 0) the left endpoint. Default: 0
Returns:

DataFrame
Raises:

NotImplementedError

See also

orca.mongo.util.cut_window()

fetch_window(dname, window, **kwargs)[source]¶

Override(mandatory) to fetch data for consecutive trading days.

Parameters:
  • dname (str) – Name of the data
  • window (list) – List of consecutive trading dates
Returns:

DataFrame
Raises:

NotImplementedError
fetch_history(dname, date, backdays, **kwargs)[source]¶

Override(mandatory) to fetch data with respect to a base point.

Parameters:
  • dname (str) – Name of the data
  • date (str, int) – The date(with additional tweaks specified in kwargs and self.delay) as a base point
  • backdays (int) – Number of days to look back w.r.t. the base point
Returns:

DataFrame
Raises:

NotImplementedError
fetch_daily(dname, date, offset=0, **kwargs)[source]¶

Override(mandatory) to fetch data series on a certain date.

Parameters:
  • dname (str) – Name of the data
  • date (str, int) – The base point
  • offset (int) – The offset w.r.t. the date. The actual fetched date is calculated from date and offset. Default: 0
Returns:

Series
Raises:

NotImplementedError

Base class to fetch daily data that can be formatted as DataFrame.

This is a base class and should not be used directly.

fetch(dname, startdate, enddate=None, backdays=0, **kwargs)[source]¶

Use fetch_window() behind the scene.

fetch_window(dname, window, **kwargs)[source]¶

Fetch data from a certain collection in MongoDB. For most cases, this is the only method that needs to be overridden.

Use fetch_window() behind the scene.

fetch_window(dname, times, window, **kwargs)[source]¶

Fetch minute-bar data(specified by time stamps) for a consecutive days.

Parameters:times (str, list) – Time stamps to indicate which minute-bars should be fetched. This will affect the returned data type
Returns:DataFrame(if type(times) is str) or Panel(with times as the item-axis)

fetch_info(dname='name', level=0, date=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Fetch industry-name/industry-index correspondance.

Parameters:
  • dname (str) – ‘name’(default): fetch industry-name mapping; ‘index’: fetch industry-index mapping
  • level (int) – Which level of industry is of interest? Default: 0, all 3 levels’ information are fetched
Return type:

dict

mongo.jyfund¶

class orca.mongo.jyfund.JYFundFetcher(table, startyear=2007, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: orca.mongo.base.KDayFetcher

Class to fetch JYDB fundamental data.

Parameters:
  • table (str) – Table name, must be one of (‘balancesheet’, ‘income’, ‘cashflow’)
  • startyear (str, int) – Fetch data starting from this year in advance, must be in the format ‘YYYY’. Default: 2007
prepare_frame(dnames=None, date=None, quarter_offset=0, rtype=1, quarter=None, delay=1, **kwargs)[source]¶

Prepare cross-sectional data items and concatenate them into a DataFrame, using data with timestamps less than date minus delay.

Parameters:
  • dnames (list) – List of data names. Default: None, all data items will be included(NOT recommended)
  • quarter_offset (int) – Offset in quarter numbers. Default: 0
  • rtype (enum) – What type of reports to be considered? QUARTER(1, default): all reports; SEMI(2): only semi-annual reports and annual reports; YEAR(4): only annual reports
  • quarter (int) – It will only fetch data for this particular quarter(the 4 quarters in a year is 1, 2, 3, 4), thus should be compatible with the use of rtype. Default: None, fetch whatever data is available

See also

JYFundFetcher.prepare_panel()

prepare_panel(dnames, startdate=None, enddate=None, rtype=1, use_adjust=None, fillna='ffill', **kwargs)[source]¶

Prepare a Panel with item axis labled by data names.

Parameters:
  • dnames (list) – List of data names
  • startdate – Starting point of data. Default: None, defaults to the earliest date
  • enddate – Ending point of data. Default: None, defaults to the last date
  • rtype (enum) – What type of reports to be considered? QUARTER(1, default): all reports; SEMI(2): only semi-annual reports; YEAR(4): only annual reports
  • use_adjust (None, boolean) – How to treat data corrections? None(default): try to use all published data along date axis. False: use only first published data. True: use only last published data which are assumed to be public up to enddate, thus may entail forward-looking bias in backtesting simulation
  • ffill (None, str) – Fill gaps long date axis for those non-reporting days, currently supports (‘ffill’, None). Default: ‘ffill’
fetch(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Disabled.

Raises:NotImplementedError
fetch_window(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Disabled.

Raises:NotImplementedError
fetch_history(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Disabled.

Raises:NotImplementedError
fetch_daily(dname, date, offset=0, quarter_offset=0, rtype=1, quarter=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Return a series of cross-sectional data.

Parameters:
  • quarter_offset (int) – Offset in quarter numbers. Default: 0
  • rtype (enum) – Which type of reports to be considered
  • quarter (int) – Should only used when rtype is QUARTER(2). It will only fetch data for this particular quarter, thus also making quarter_offset not meaningful. Default: None, fetch whatever data is available as of date-offset

class orca.mongo.barra.BarraExposureFetcher(model, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: orca.mongo.barra.BarraFetcher

Class to fetch stock to factor exposure.

fetch_daily(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

This differs from the default orca.mongo.base.KDayFetcher.fetch_daily() in only one aspect: when the dname is not given, this will fetch all factors exposure on date.

Returns:Series(if a factor name is given), DataFrame(all factor names are in the columns)

mongo.util¶

orca.mongo.util.is_sorted(l, ascending=True)[source]¶

Check if a list is sorted.

orca.mongo.util.find_ge(l, x)[source]¶

Find the leftmost item in the sorted(ascending) list >= x.

orca.mongo.util.find_le(l, x)[source]¶

Find the rightmost item in the sorted(ascending) list <= x

orca.mongo.util.parse_date(dates, date, direction=1)[source]¶

Find the item in dates that is closest(specified by direction) to date

Parameters:
  • dates (list) – The pre-defined list, must be sorted in ascending order
  • date – date may be already in dates; otherwise, it will be parsed into another item in the list
  • direction (int) – 1(default): the desired item >= date;-1: the desired item <= date
Returns:

(i, dates[i]), i is the index of the desired item in dates
orca.mongo.util.compliment_datestring(datestr, direction=-1, date_check=False)[source]¶

Compliment a 4- or 6-length date string into 8-length in format yyyymmdd.

Parameters:
  • datestr (str) – For example, ‘2014’, ‘201401’ or ‘20140101’
  • direction (int) – -1(default): compliment as the minimal possible; 1: compliment as the maximal possible
  • date_check (boolean) – Whether to check if datestr is a valid date string. Default: False
orca.mongo.util.cut_window(dates, startdate, enddate=None, backdays=0)[source]¶

Cut out the portion of a list specified by left and right endpoints.

Parameters:
  • dates (list) – The pre-defined list, must be sorted in ascending order
  • startdate – The left (may not be the actual) cut-out point
  • enddate – The right cut-out point. Default: None, defaults to the last item in the list
  • backdays (int) – This will shift (left/right: >/< 0) the left cut-out point. Default: 0
Returns:

The cut-out portion
Return type:

list
orca.mongo.util.generate_timestamps(starttime, endtime, step, end_excluded=True)[source]¶

Generate consecutive time stamps.

Parameters:
  • starttime, endtime (str) – Must be 6-length time string in the format ‘hhmmss’
  • step (int) – Number of seconds as step
  • end_excluded (boolean) – Whether the endtime itself should be excluded from the result. Default: True
Returns:
